Box 1: No - You’re correct. Resource groups in Azure are logical containers for resources deployed on Azure, and there is no cost for the resource group itself12.

Box 2: No - Indeed, all inbound or ingress data transfers to Azure data centers from on-premises environments are free3.

Box 3: Yes - That’s correct. Data egress over a VPN is data ‘going out’ of Azure over the VPN, and you are charged for data egress453. However, please note that Azure now offers free egress for customers leaving Azure when taking their data out of the Azure infrastructure via the internet to switch to another cloud provider or an on-premises data center6. Azure already offers the first 100GB/month of egressed data for free to all customers in all Azure regions around the world.

Lets add to the confusion on this one and feel free to comment: Actually the answer is: No, No and No. We agreed that ingress is free and that egress is charged. But in both cases the VPN-Gateway is charged for being provisioned and available by the hour. So we're already paying for bi-directional VPN traffic regardless of the traffic volume. IMO: Egress data to the data-center is therefore is charged at zone rates without additional costs.

Box 1: No
Resource groups are logical containers for Azure resources. You do not pay for resource groups.
Box 2: Yes
Data ingress over a VPN is data ‘coming in’ to Azure over the VPN. You are charged data transfer costs for
data ingress.
Box 3: No
Data egress over a VPN is data ‘going out’ of Azure over the VPN. You are not charged for data egress.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/manage-resource-groups-portal
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/pricing/details/bandwidth/

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: No -
Resource groups are logical containers for Azure resources. You do not pay for resource groups.

Box 2: No -
Data ingress over a VPN is data 'coming in' to Azure over the VPN. You are not charged data transfer costs for data ingress.

Box 3: Yes -
Data egress over a VPN is data 'going out' of Azure over the VPN. You are charged for data egress.

The Basic support plan does not include the ability to open a new support request for technical support 1. The correct answer is C. Premier, Professional Direct, Standard, and Developer only.

Selected Answer: D
All Azure support plans allow you to open support tickets with Microsoft. However, the level of support you receive may vary depending on the plan you have. 
Here is a summary of the support plans and the level of support they provide:
1. Basic: Provides 24/7 technical support for Azure portal and billing issues through online and email channels, but does not provide a guaranteed response time for support tickets.
2. Developer: Provides standard technical support for Azure issues during business hours, with a guaranteed initial response time of 12 hours for support tickets.
3. Standard: Provides standard technical support for Azure issues 24/7, with a guaranteed initial response time of 1 hour for critical issues and 4 hours for non-critical issues.
4. Professional Direct: Provides personalized technical support with a dedicated technical account manager and faster response times than the standard plan.
5. Premier: Provides the highest level of technical support with a dedicated support team, personalized service, and faster response times than the other plans.

comments.content: True words my friend! I think we all feel that way! I completed my first Microsoft exam 23 years ago and I can assure you. NOTHING has changed, nor will it!

discussion.content: I have read many of the discussions on questions where the answer I believed to be correct and the supplied answer were at odds, and been impressed with the cogent reasoning and responses. And yet, in the end, I am still left in doubt as to which answer will score me a point on the exam, as too many of these discussions are not about the features and functions of Azure, and which are best suited to which scenario, but arguments about how to correctly interpret the question . It just seems like it doesn't matter how much you actually know about Azure, if you are unfortunate enough to get too many of these badly designed questions, you are still reduced to guessing at the answer. I don't know if Microsoft think they are being clever doing this, or they just don't care that the questions are bad, but either way, it reduces what should be a test of knowledge, to a game show farce.

comments.content: yes thanks for sharing

discussion.content: Availability Regions contain Availability Zones (Datacenters). If you have a mission-critical app that your customers require access to frequently, you would want redundancy for your databases, meaning you would like to have copies of databases spread across different yet nearby AZs. Hence, in an event of a failure, your AZ should have "Fault Tolerance" Capability.
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
Fault tolerance ensures that a system continues to function even if some of its components fail.
In the context of Azure, this means deploying servers across multiple Availability Zones or using Azure Site Recovery to maintain availability in case of a data center failure.
This strategy prevents downtime due to a single point of failure in one Azure region.

Selected Answer: A
Fault Tolerance refers to the ability of a system or application to continue operating without disruption in the event of a failure. This is achieved through redundancy and failover mechanisms that ensure that if one component fails, another component takes over seamlessly, without any downtime or interruption of service.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct 

Fault Tolerance

Fault tolerance is about maintaining operations during a failure.
Reliability is about minimizing failures over time.

Selected Answer: A
fault tolerance

Hence, in an event of a failure, your AZ should have "Fault Tolerance" Capability.

comments.content: No. Disaster recovery is beeing able to restoring from backup. Fault tolerance is continue to function with some parts broken (hard disk, a VM or a datacenter).

questions.question_text:
You have an on-premises network that contains several servers.
You plan to migrate all the servers to Azure.
You need to recommend a solution to ensure that some of the servers are available if a single Azure data center goes offline for an extended period.
What should you include in the recommendation?
